subject: EU Legislation and Decision-Making Procedures
key_concepts: Balance between EU Integration and Member State Sovereignty
Tobacco Products Directive (TPD) as Case Study
reason: This material covers fundamental institutional mechanics of EU governance - legislative procedures, legal instruments, and inter-institutional dynamics are core to understanding how the EU functions. These topics are frequently tested in EU politics, law, and governance exams at both undergraduate and graduate levels. The case study approach (TPD) provides concrete application of theoretical concepts.
likely_exam_questions: Compare and contrast Regulations and Directives, explaining their legal effects and political purposes
Outline the ordinary legislative procedure, identifying key actors and decision points
Explain how qualified majority voting works and why member states often avoid formal voting
Discuss the role of national parliaments in EU decision-making with reference to the subsidiarity principle
Analyze why certain policy areas use different legal instruments or decision-making procedures
Using the Tobacco Products Directive case, illustrate how EU institutions interact in practice
Explain the distinction between 'direct applicability' and 'direct effect'
Compare decision-making in CFSP with other policy areas
connections: Treaty on European Union (TEU) and Treaty on Functioning (TFEU)
difficulty_spikes: Distinguishing between direct applicability (Regulations) and direct effect (certain Directives)
Understanding the political logic behind instrument choice in sensitive policy areas
Qualified Majority Voting calculations and their political implications
The blurred distinction between detailed Directives and Regulations in practice
CFSP's separate legal instruments and intergovernmental logic
prerequisites: Basic knowledge of EU institutions (Commission, Council, Parliament)
Understanding of EU treaties as constitutional framework
Familiarity with EU integration theories (supranationalism vs. intergovernmentalism)
Concept of sovereignty in EU context
summary: This chapter examines EU decision-making procedures, focusing on the ordinary legislative procedure as the primary method for adopting legislation. It analyzes the four main legal instruments (Regulations, Directives, Decisions, Recommendations/Opinions) and their political significance in balancing EU integration with member state sovereignty. Using the Tobacco Products Directive as a case study, it illustrates how institutions interact in practice, highlighting the roles of qualified majority voting, national parliaments, and alternative decision-making methods.
